sub_topic: Calculation of Gibbs free energy change for a chemical reaction
message_1:
What is the Gibbs free energy change at 25°C for the reaction: 

2NO(g) + O2(g) → 2NO2(g) 

given that the standard Gibbs free energy of formation of NO, O2, and NO2 are +90.4 kJ/mol, 0 kJ/mol and +51.3 kJ/mol, respectively?
message_2:
To calculate the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔG = Σ ΔGf(products) - Σ ΔGf(reactants)

where ΔGf represents the standard Gibbs free energy of formation of the respective compounds.

For the given reaction:

2NO(g) + O2(g) → 2NO2(g)

ΔG = [2 × ΔGf(NO2)] - [2 × ΔGf(NO) + ΔGf(O2)]

We are given the standard Gibbs free energy of formation for NO, O2, and NO2 as +90.4 kJ/mol, 0 kJ/mol, and +51.3 kJ/mol, respectively.

Substitute the given values into the equation:

ΔG = [2 × (+51.3 kJ/mol)] - [2 × (+90.4 kJ/mol) + 0 kJ/mol]

ΔG = [102.6 kJ/mol] - [180.8 kJ/mol]

ΔG = -78.2 kJ/mol

The Gibbs free energy change at 25°C for the reaction is -78.2 kJ/mol.
